FeedItems.Summary:

FeedItems.Summary:
NuGet.org will begin requiring two-factor authentication for accounts starting March 8th.
The post Requiring two-factor authentication on NuGet.org appeared first on The NuGet Blog.

Events.RelatedDescription: Opened issue "[NuGet.org Bug]: The search bar disappears when browsing packages under a package owner" (#9377) at NuGet/NuGetGallery
Events.RelatedBody:
### Impact

I'm unable to use NuGet.org

### Describe the bug

I remember that there is always a search bar when browsing packages under a package owner, but it disappears recently:
![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/41028779/216486932-d0917271-fbde-4db6-95d8-238be16a6314.png)


### Repro Steps

1. Go to a package owner profile page: https://www.nuget.org/profiles/dotnetframework
2. No search bar any more

### Expected Behavior

The search bar should be there as before when browsing packages under a package owner.

### Screenshots

_No response_

### Additional Context and logs

_No response_

Events.RelatedDescription: Opened issue "[NuGet.org Bug]: A second search bar blinks when changing the selection of "Sort by"" (#9376) at NuGet/NuGetGallery
Events.RelatedBody:
### Impact

It bothers me. A fix would be nice

### Describe the bug

When changing the selection of "Sort by", a second search bar is shown and then disappears.
![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/41028779/216483097-ec029bc6-a913-44a1-bf0b-99bff2fbeb75.png)

### Repro Steps

1. Go to the search page in Gallery
2. Change the selection of "Sort by"
3. A second search bar blinks

### Expected Behavior

It should not blink for a better experience.

### Screenshots

_No response_

### Additional Context and logs

_No response_

Events.RelatedDescription: Opened issue "[Search-by-TFM Bug Bash] Box around the TFM section arrows is hidden by the box below it" (#9375) at NuGet/NuGetGallery
Events.RelatedBody:
### Problem description
The box around the framework generation collapsible arrows (when they're selected/in focus) is distorted by the box below it. Some of the bottom part of the box gets hidden.

Events.RelatedDescription: Merged pull request "redirect to external privacy link" (#9347) at NuGet/NuGetGallery
Events.RelatedBody:
Privacy page https://www.nuget.org/policies/Privacy redirect to generic Microsoft privacy policy.

Addresses https://github.com/NuGet/Engineering/issues/4669

Events.RelatedDescription: Opened issue "[Search-by-TFM Bug Bash] Make filters panel collapsible on mobile devices or narrow screens" (#9374) at NuGet/NuGetGallery
Events.RelatedBody:
### Problem description
The filters panel appears vertically above the search results on mobile devices and narrow screens, and the important search results are pushed to the bottom of the screen, and the user may even have to scroll to get to them, especially when the TFM sections are expanded. The search results should be the most prominent and visible feature on the page when it loads.

### Solution
Make the filters panel collapsible on mobile (and narrow screens). Have the collapsible icon after the 'There are x packages' text, in keeping with current nuget.org. Hide the 'sort by' by default too.

Events.RelatedDescription: Opened issue "[Search-by-TFM Bug Bash] Empty query string parameters should be left out of the url entirely" (#9373) at NuGet/NuGetGallery
Events.RelatedBody:
### Problem description
Empty query string parameters are included in the url, and the url looks unnecessarily cluttered.

https://dev.nugettest.org/packages?q=&packagetype=&frameworks=&tfms=net472%2Cnet47%2C&prerel=True&sortby=relevance

### Solution
Empty query string parameters should be left out of the url entirely.

https://dev.nugettest.org/packages?tfms=net472%2Cnet47&prerel=True&sortby=relevance

Events.RelatedDescription: Opened issue "[Search-by-TFM] Users might expect to see computed compatible packages when filtering by TFMs" (#9372) at NuGet/NuGetGallery
Events.RelatedBody:
### Problem description
People might expect to see computed compatible packages in their search results, rather than just asset frameworks. Package authors use .Net Standard TFMs to be compatible across a range of other frameworks, and their package not showing up as a search result despite being compatible might be a problem.

Eg. People will expect packages targeting netstandard2.0 to show up with most framework selections, since it is compatible with most TFMs, but since we only consider explicit asset TFMs, a user searching for net462 packages will not see compatible netstandard2.0 packages even though they should. 

### Solution
Include computed compatible frameworks in the filtering experience.

Events.RelatedDescription: Opened issue "[Search-by-TFM Bug Bash] packageType param should appear after frameworks and tfms in the url" (#9371) at NuGet/NuGetGallery
Events.RelatedBody:
### Problem description
The packageType query parameter appears before frameworks and tfms in the url, but appears after them in the UI.

### Solution
The frameworks and tfms params should appear before packageType in the url.

Events.RelatedDescription: Opened issue "[Search-by-TFM Bug Bash] TFM section should be expanded on page load if a TFM is selected" (#9370) at NuGet/NuGetGallery
Events.RelatedBody:
### Problem description
All TFM sections are collapsed when the page loads, even if a TFM is selected, because of which users can't see their selected TFMs.

### Solution
If any individual TFMs have been selected, their TFM sections should be expanded when the page loads.

Events.RelatedDescription: Opened issue "[Search-by-TFM Bug Bash] Frameworks and tfms params have a trailing comma" (#9369) at NuGet/NuGetGallery
Events.RelatedBody:
### Problem description
The frameworks and tfms parameters always end in a comma (`net,` ; `net5.0,net472,`).

### Solution
Remove the trailing comma.

Events.RelatedDescription: Opened issue "[Search-by-TFM Bug Bash] Frameworks and tfms params not ordered correctly" (#9368) at NuGet/NuGetGallery
Events.RelatedBody:
### Problem description
The frameworks and tfms parameters are being added to the query string in the order that the user selects them, rather than the order of the checkboxes in the UI.

### Solution
Frameworks and tfms should appear in the url in the order they appear in the UI.

Events.RelatedDescription: Opened issue "[Search-by-TFM Bug Bash] Prerel parameter uppercase/lowercase inconsistency" (#9367) at NuGet/NuGetGallery
Events.RelatedBody:
### Problem description
The Prerelease url parameter sometimes has an uppercase boolean ('True') and sometimes a lowercase boolean ('true').

### Solution
It should always show a lowercase boolean.

Events.RelatedDescription: Opened pull request "Search-by-TFM Bug Bash feedback" (#9366) at NuGet/NuGetGallery
Events.RelatedBody:
Addresses 

This PR addresses some of the issues flagged by the Search-by-TFM bug bash:

1. The Prerelease url parameter sometimes had an uppercase boolean ('True') and sometimes a lowercase boolean ('true'). It will always show a lowercase boolean now.
2. The frameworks and tfms parameters were being added to the query string in the order that the user selected them, rather than the order of the checkboxes in the UI. This has been fixed.
3. The frameworks and tfms parameters always ended in a comma (`net,` ; `net5.0,net472,`). This has been fixed.
4. Previously, all TFM sections were always collapsed when the page loaded. Now, if any individual TFMs have been selected, their TFM sections will be expanded when the page loads.
5. The packageType query parameter was before frameworks and tfms in the url, but appears after them in the UI. This has been fixed so that the frameworks and tfms params appear before packageType in the url.

Events.RelatedDescription: Closed issue "[Bug]: Static graph restore binlog doesn't have evaluation data" (#11485) at NuGet/Home
Events.RelatedBody:
### NuGet Product Used

MSBuild.exe

### Product Version

msbuild 17

### Worked before?

_No response_

### Impact

It's more difficult to complete my work

### Repro Steps & Context

```
SET RESTORE_TASK_BINLOG_PARAMETERS=LogFile=%cd%\nuget.binlog
msbuild /t:restore /bl /p:RestoreUseStaticGraphEvaluation=true
```

Inspect `nuget.binlog` and notice the Evaluation node is empty/childless:
![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/6445614/148473245-8fd041eb-d414-4ef7-be1a-28ddfabf5d72.png)

It should look more like this:
![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/6445614/148473334-b1f82a0a-88e0-4f28-9e89-04b7684f1c6f.png)


### Verbose Logs

_No response_

Events.RelatedDescription: Opened issue "Misleading error message during NuGet Restore when not authenticated to a feed" (#12403) at NuGet/Home
Events.RelatedBody:
### NuGet Product Used

NuGet.exe

### Product Version

6.4.0

### Worked before?

No

### Impact

It's more difficult to complete my work

### Repro Steps & Context

An error message occurs during a NuGet Restore action when the current user context is not properly authenticated to the referenced feed.

For example:

> NU1301: Unable to load the service index for source `{source}`

This error occurs during an Azure DevOps pipeline build when the project-scoped build identity [`{Project Name} Build Service ({Org Name})`](https://learn.microsoft.com/en-us/azure/devops/pipelines/process/access-tokens?view=azure-devops-2022&tabs=yaml#scoped-build-identities) is omitted from the referenced feed's permissions (assuming an Azure DevOps feed).

The fix for this is very easy—simply add the project-scoped build identity to the feed's permissions.

Unfortunately, however, the error message is very misleading. It doesn't describe the root problem, leaving developers and DevOps engineers in the dark as to how to address it. The abundance of reports and attempted/failed solutions found at StackOverflow and elsewhere attest to this.

To reproduce:

1. In Azure DevOps (Services or Server), create a new collection-scoped feed
2. Note that the feed's permissions do not include the project-scoped build identity
3. Publish a package to the feed
4. Create a Git repository
5. Create a pipeline build that consumes the repository and is triggered by a `git push`
6. Add a `nuget restore` step to the pipeline
7. In the `nuget restore` step, reference the feed
8. Create a Visual Studio project that references the package
9. `git push` the code to the repository
10. Note the misleading error message in the build's logs
11. Add the project-scoped build identity to the feed's permissions
12. Run the pipeline again (afresh, not a rerun)
13. Note that the error no longer occurs

The message can be adjusted to more accurately reflect the error it attempts to describe.


### Verbose Logs

